<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 170, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/41  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 245, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 485, 574]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 652]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 213, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 697, 384, 712]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 712, 728, 728]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(12\mathrm{kg}\) is being pulled by a rope up a rough plane. The plane is inclined at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) above the horizontal. The rope pulling the block is parallel to a line of greatest slope of the plane. The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is 0.4. The acceleration of the block is \(2\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 339, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the rope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[86, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 82, 670, 228]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 240, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
Three coplanar forces of magnitudes \(P\mathrm{N}\), \(5\mathrm{N}\) and \(10\mathrm{N}\) act at a point \(O\), as shown in the diagram. The resultant of the three forces has magnitude \(Q\mathrm{N}\) and acts in a direction perpendicular to the force of magnitude \(P\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 425, 322]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(P\) and the value of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 304, 918, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 87, 816, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 295, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the velocity-time graph of the motion of a cyclist. The graph consists of three straight line segments. The cyclist passes a point \(O\) with speed \(3 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) and then accelerates for \(10 \mathrm{~s}\) with constant acceleration \(0.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 2}\). He then travels at constant speed for \(30 \mathrm{~s}\) before decelerating, coming to rest at point \(P\), covering a distance of \(80 \mathrm{~m}\) whilst decelerating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 144, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 373, 574, 392]]<|/det|>
Find the total time taken for the journey from \(O\) to \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 373, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 71, 586, 89]]<|/det|>
A lorry of mass \(18 000 \mathrm{~kg}\) is travelling along a straight road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
On a horizontal section of the road, the power of the lorry's engine is constant. There is a constant resistance to motion of \(1600 \mathrm{~N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
The steady speed which the lorry can maintain with the engine working at power \(P \mathrm{~W}\) is \(30 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 193, 351, 211]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 194, 918, 212]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 408, 178, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 408, 920, 426]]<|/det|>
At an instant when the speed of the lorry is \(16 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), its engine is working at a power of \(40 \mathrm{kW}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 437, 918, 456]]<|/det|>
Find the acceleration of the lorry at this instant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 648, 146, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 648, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
When the lorry has reached a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), it begins to ascend a section of road inclined at an angle \(\alpha^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The engine now works at a power of \(120 \mathrm{kW}\). There is no change in the lorry's speed as it ascends the hill. The constant resistance to motion remains \(1600 \mathrm{~N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 710, 311, 727]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 912, 96]]<|/det|>
When a particle \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{kg}\) has speed \(u \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\), its momentum is \(4 \mathrm{Ns}\) and its kinetic energy is \(16 \mathrm{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 458, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(m\) and the value of \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 384, 920, 439]]<|/det|>
\(P\) is now projected on a smooth horizontal surface with speed \(v \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) directly towards a particle \(Q\) of mass \(1.25 \mathrm{kg}\) which is stationary. After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, the velocity of \(P\) is \(w \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) and the velocity of \(Q\) is \(2w \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\). The loss of kinetic energy in the collision is \(25 \mathrm{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 146, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 455, 470]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(v\) and the value of \(w\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 451, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 81, 791, 215]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 233, 920, 330]]<|/det|>
Two particles, \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.6 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a smooth pulley fixed at a point \(B\) where the inclined planes \(AB\) and \(BC\) meet. \(P\) lies on the smooth plane \(AB\) which is inclined at an angle \(\theta^{\circ}\) to the horizontal where \(\sin \theta^{\circ} = 0.4\) . \(Q\) lies on the plane \(BC\) which is inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The string is taut and the particles can move on lines of greatest slope of the two planes (see diagram). The particles are released from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 343, 144, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 343, 460, 361]]<|/det|>
It is given that the plane \(BC\) is smooth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 373, 588, 392]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string and the acceleration of \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 374, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 146, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the plane \(BC\) is rough. The work done against the frictional force when \(Q\) moves \(2 \text{m}\) down the plane is \(1.8 \text{J}\). You should assume that \(P\) does **not** reach the pulley and that \(Q\) does **not** reach \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 131, 816, 149]]<|/det|>
Use an energy method to find the speed of \(Q\) when it has moved \(2 \text{m}\) down the plane. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 922, 112]]<|/det|>
A particle \(X\) moves along a straight track, starting from a point \(O\) at time \(t = 0\). The displacement of \(X\) from \(O\) at time \(t\) s is \(s\) m, where \(s = 3t^{\frac{3}{2}} - 6t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 123, 146, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 123, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
Find the time at which \(X\) is instantaneously at rest, and hence find the total distance travelled by \(X\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 16\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
A second particle \(Y\) moves along another straight track, starting from a point \(P\) at time \(t = 0\). The acceleration of \(Y\) at time \(t\)s is \(a \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 2}\), where \(a = 0.8 - 0.6t\). The velocity of \(Y\) when it leaves \(P\) is \(7.5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 135, 148, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
When the velocity of \(Y\) is \(-9.6 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\), show that the displacement of \(X\) from \(O\) is equal to the displacement of \(Y\) from \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
